Sentence 1: Cornish Pasty [kɔːnɪʃ pæstɪ] (Wortursprung Französisch: Paste/Pasta – eine Pastete mit beliebigem Inhalt, die ohne Geschirr und Besteck gegessen werden kann) ist die Bezeichnung für eine englische Version der Fleischpastete, die mit der Region um Cornwall assoziiert wird.
Sentence 2: Un pasty est une sorte de pâtisserie salée, britannique d'origine, dont une forme particulière est traditionnellement associée avec les Cornouailles,.

Sentence 1: Cornish Pasty [kɔːnɪʃ pæstɪ] (Wortursprung Französisch: Paste/Pasta – eine Pastete mit beliebigem Inhalt, die ohne Geschirr und Besteck gegessen werden kann) ist die Bezeichnung für eine englische Version der Fleischpastete, die mit der Region um Cornwall assoziiert wird.
Sentence 2: Un pasty se prépare en plaçant une garniture, généralement de la viande et des légumes, sur la moitié d'une abaisse que l'on rabat en pressant les bords pour les refermer et former une poche refermant le contenu.

Sentence 1: Cornish Pasty [kɔːnɪʃ pæstɪ] (Wortursprung Französisch: Paste/Pasta – eine Pastete mit beliebigem Inhalt, die ohne Geschirr und Besteck gegessen werden kann) ist die Bezeichnung für eine englische Version der Fleischpastete, die mit der Region um Cornwall assoziiert wird.
Sentence 2: Le pasty se cuit au four.

Sentence 1: Cornish Pasty [kɔːnɪʃ pæstɪ] (Wortursprung Französisch: Paste/Pasta – eine Pastete mit beliebigem Inhalt, die ohne Geschirr und Besteck gegessen werden kann) ist die Bezeichnung für eine englische Version der Fleischpastete, die mit der Region um Cornwall assoziiert wird.
Sentence 2: Le pasty est proche d'une tourte, mais généralement avec une garniture dans une pâte rabattue, plutôt qu'entre deux abaisses, et formé sans moule à tarte.

Sentence 1: Cornish Pasty [kɔːnɪʃ pæstɪ] (Wortursprung Französisch: Paste/Pasta – eine Pastete mit beliebigem Inhalt, die ohne Geschirr und Besteck gegessen werden kann) ist die Bezeichnung für eine englische Version der Fleischpastete, die mit der Region um Cornwall assoziiert wird.
Sentence 2: Les origines du pasty sont incertaines mais on dénombre d'amples références à travers des documents historiques et de la fiction.

Sentence 2: A pasty () is a British baked pastry, a traditional variety of which is particularly associated with Cornwall, South West England, but has spread all over the British Isles, and elsewhere through the Cornish diaspora.

Sentence 2: It is made by placing an uncooked filling, typically meat and vegetables, in the middle of a flat shortcrust pastry circle, bringing the edges together in the middle, and crimping over the top to form a seal before baking.

Pen's ... on a damned venison pasty, that stunk like a devil", but after this period the use of the word outside Devon and Cornwall declined.In contrast to its earlier place amongst the wealthy, during the 17th and 18th centuries, the pasty became popular with working people in Cornwall and west Devon, where tin miners and others adopted it because of its unique shape, forming a complete meal that could be carried easily and eaten without cutlery.

== Culture ==
=== Literature ===

=== Superstitions, rhymes and chants ===

=== Shape ===

=== Literature ===
Pasties have been mentioned in multiple literary works since the 12th century Arthurian romance Erec and Enide, written by Chrétien de Troyes, in which they are eaten by characters from the area now known as Cornwall.

=== Superstitions, rhymes and chants ===

Sentence 2: The pasty is now popular worldwide because of the spread of Cornish miners and sailors from across Cornwall, and variations can be found in Australia, Mexico, the United States, Ulster and elsewhere.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: Pasties resemble turnovers from many other cuisines and cultures, including the bridie in Scotland, empanada in Spanish-speaking countries, pirog in Eastern Europe, samsa in Central Asia, and the curry puff in Southeast Asia.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.

== History ==
Despite the modern pasty's strong association with Cornwall, its origins are unclear.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: The English word "pasty" derives from Medieval French (O.Fr.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: paste from V.Lat pasta) for a pie, filled with venison, salmon or other meat, vegetables or cheese, baked without a dish.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: Pasties have been mentioned in cookbooks throughout the ages.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: For example, the earliest version of Le Viandier (Old French) has been dated to c. 1300 and contains several pasty recipes.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: In 1393, Le Menagier de Paris contains recipes for pasté with venison, veal, beef, or mutton.Other early references to pasties include a 13th-century charter that was granted by King John of England (in 1208) to the town of Great Yarmouth.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: The town was bound to send to the sheriffs of Norwich every year one hundred herrings, baked in twenty four pasties, which the sheriffs delivered to the lord of the manor of East Carlton who then conveyed them to the king.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: Around the same time, 13th-century chronicler Matthew Paris wrote of the monks of St Albans Abbey "according to their custom, lived upon pasties of flesh-meat".

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: In 1465, 5,500 venison pasties were served at the installation feast of George Neville, archbishop of York and chancellor of England.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: The earliest reference for a pasty in Devon or Cornwall can be found in Plymouth city records of 1509/10, which describe "Itm for the cooke is labor to make the pasties 10d".

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: They were even eaten by royalty, as a letter from a baker to Henry VIII's third wife Jane Seymour confirms: "...hope this pasty reaches you in better condition than the last one ..." In his diaries written in the mid-17th century, Samuel Pepys makes several references to his consumption of pasties, for instance "dined at Sir W. Pen's ... on a damned venison pasty, that stunk like a devil", but after this period the use of the word outside Devon and Cornwall declined.In contrast to its earlier place amongst the wealthy, during the 17th and 18th centuries, the pasty became popular with working people in Cornwall and west Devon, where tin miners and others adopted it because of its unique shape, forming a complete meal that could be carried easily and eaten without cutlery.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: In a mine, the pasty's dense, folded pastry could stay warm for several hours, and if it did get cold, it could easily be warmed on a shovel over a candle.Side-crimped pasties gave rise to the suggestion that the miner might have eaten the pasty holding the thick edge of pastry, which was later discarded, thereby ensuring that dirty fingers (possibly including traces of arsenic) did not touch the food or mouth.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: However, many old photographs show that pasties were wrapped in bags made of paper or muslin and were eaten from end to end; according to the earliest Cornish recipe book, published in 1929, this is "the true Cornish way" to eat a pasty.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: Another theory suggests that pasties were marked at one end with an initial and then eaten from the other end so that if not finished in one sitting, they could easily be reclaimed by their owners.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2:
== Cornish pasty ==
The pasty is regarded as the national dish of Cornwall, and an early reference is from a New Zealand newspaper:In Cornwall, there is a common practice among those cottagers who bake at home of making little pasties for the dinners of those who may be working at a distance in the fields.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: They will last the whole week, and are made of any kind of meat or fruit, rolled up in a paste made of flour and suet or lard.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: A couple of ounces of bacon and half a-pound of raw potatoes, both thinly sliced and slightly seasoned, will be found sufficient for the meal.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: The pasty can be carried in the man's pocket.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: The term "Cornish pasty" has been in use since at least the early 1860s:The Cornish pasty, which so admirably comprises a dinner in itself—meat, potatoes, and other good things well cooked and made up into so portable a form—was a subject of much admiration, and reminded me of the old coaching days, when I secured a pasty at Bodmin in order to take it home to my cook, that it might be dissected and serve as a pattern for Cornish pasties in quite another part of the country.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: Cornish pasties are very popular with the working classes in this neighbourhood, and have lately been successfully introduced into some parts of Devonshire.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: They are made of small pieces of beef, and thin slices of potato, highly peppered, and enclosed in wrappers of paste.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: By the late 19th century, national cookery schools began to teach their pupils to create their own version of a "Cornish pasty" that was smaller and was to be eaten as an "economical savoury nibble for polite middle-class Victorians".On 20 July 2011, after a nine-year campaign by the Cornish Pasty Association (CPA) – the trade organisation of about 50 pasty makers based in Cornwall – the name "Cornish pasty" was awarded Protected Geographical Indication (PGI) status by the European Commission.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: According to the PGI status, a Cornish pasty should be shaped like a 'D' and crimped on one side, not on the top.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: Its ingredients should include beef, swede (called turnip in Cornwall), potato and onion, with a light seasoning of salt and pepper, keeping a chunky texture.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: The pastry should be golden and retain its shape when cooked and cooled.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: The PGI status also means that Cornish pasties must be prepared in Cornwall.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: They do not have to be baked in Cornwall, nor do the ingredients have to come from the county, though the CPA notes that there are strong links between pasty production and local suppliers of the ingredients.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: Packaging for pasties that conform to the requirements includes an authentication stamp, the use of which is policed by the CPA.Producers outside Cornwall objected to the PGI award, with one saying "[EU bureaucrats could] go to hell", and another that it was "protectionism for some big pasty companies to churn out a pastiche of the real iconic product".

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: Major UK supermarkets Asda and Morrisons both stated they would be affected by the change, as did nationwide bakery chain Greggs, though Greggs was one of seven companies allowed to continue to use the name "Cornish pasty" during a three-year transitional period.Members of the CPA made about 87 million pasties in 2008, amounting to sales of £60 million (about 6% of the food economy of Cornwall).

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: In 2011, over 1,800 permanent staff were employed by members of the CPA and some 13,000 other jobs benefited from the trade.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: Surveys by the South West tourism board have shown that one of the top three reasons people visit Cornwall is the food and that the Cornish pasty is the food most associated with Cornwall.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2:
== Definition and ingredients ==
The recipe for a Cornish pasty, as defined by its protected status, includes diced or minced beef, onion, potato and swede in rough chunks along with some "light peppery" seasoning.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: The cut of beef used is generally skirt steak.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: Swede is sometimes called turnip in Cornwall, but the recipe requires use of actual swede, not turnip.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: Pasty ingredients are usually seasoned with salt and pepper, depending on individual taste.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: The use of carrot in a traditional Cornish pasty is frowned upon, though it does appear regularly in recipes.The type of pastry used is not defined, as long as it is golden in colour and will not crack during the cooking or cooling, although modern pasties almost always use a shortcrust pastry.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: There is a humorous belief that the pastry on a good pasty should be strong enough to withstand a drop down a mine shaft, and indeed the barley flour that was usually used does make hard dense pastry.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2:
=== Variations ===
Although the officially protected Cornish pasty has a specific ingredients list, old Cornish cookery books show that pasties were generally made from whatever food was available.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: Indeed, the earliest recorded pasty recipes include venison, not beef.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: "Pasty" has always been a generic name for the shape and can contain a variety of fillings, including stilton, vegetarian and even chicken tikka.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: Pork and apple pasties are readily available in shops throughout Cornwall and Devon, with the ingredients including an apple flavoured sauce, mixed together throughout the pasty, as well as sweet pasties with ingredients such as apple and fig or chocolate and banana, which are common in some areas of Cornwall.A part-savoury, part-sweet pasty (similar to the Bedfordshire clanger) was eaten by miners in the 19th century, in the copper mines on Parys Mountain, Anglesey.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: The technician who did the research and discovered the recipe claimed that the recipe was probably taken to Anglesey by Cornish miners travelling to the area looking for work.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: No two-course pasties are commercially produced in Cornwall today, but are usually the product of amateur cooks.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: They are, however, commercially available in the British supermarket chain Morrisons (under the name 'Tin Miner Pasty').

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: Other traditional fillings have included a wide variety of locally available meats including pork, bacon, egg, rabbit, chicken, mackerel and sweet fillings such as dates, apples, jam and sweetened rice - leading to the oft-quoted joke that 'the Devil hisself was afeared to cross over into Cornwall for fear that ee'd end up in a pasty'.A pasty is known as a "tiddy oggy" when steak is replaced with an extra potato, "tiddy" meaning potato and "oggy" meaning pasty and was eaten when times were hard and expensive meat could not be afforded.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: Another traditional meatless recipe is 'herby pie' with parsley, freshly gathered wild green herbs and chives, ramsons or leeks and a spoonful of clotted cream.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2:
=== Shape ===
Whilst the PGI rules state that a Cornish pasty must be a "D" shape, with crimping along the curve (i.e., side-crimped), crimping is variable within both Devon and Cornwall, with some advocating a side crimp while others maintain that a top crimp is more authentic.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: Some sources state that the difference between a Devon and a Cornish pasty is that a Devon pasty has a top-crimp and is oval in shape, whereas the Cornish pasty is semicircular and side-crimped along the curve.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: However, pasties with a top crimp have been made in Cornwall for generations, yet those Cornish bakers who favour this method now find that they cannot legally call their pasties "Cornish".

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: Paul Hollywood, writing for BBC Food, stated that a traditional Cornish pasty should have about 20 crimps.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2:
=== Legal aspects ===
In 2001, a small American grocery and caterer in Gaylord, Michigan,  Albie's Food, Inc., was sent a cease and desist letter from another US-based food company, The J.M.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: Smucker Company, accusing Albie's of violating their intellectual property rights to the "sealed crustless sandwich".

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: Instead of capitulating, Albie's took the case to federal court, noting in their filings that a pocket sandwich with crimped edges and no crust was called a "pasty" and had been a popular dish in northern Michigan since the nineteenth century.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: The Federal Court determined that Albie's Foods did not infringe on J.M.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: Smucker's intellectual property rights and was allowed to continue.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2:
== In other regions ==
Migrating Devonian and Cornish miners and their families (colloquially known as Cousin Jacks and Cousin Jennies) helped to spread pasties into the rest of the world during the 19th century.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: As tin mining in Devon and Cornwall began to decline, miners took their expertise and traditions to new mining regions around the world.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2:
As a result, pasties can be found in many regions, including:
Many parts of Australia, including the Yorke Peninsula, which has been the site of an annual Cornish festival (claimed to be the world's largest) since 1973.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: A clarification of the Protected Geographical Status ruling has confirmed that pasties made in Australia are still allowed to be called "Cornish Pasties".

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: A Lancashire pasty is a traditional variant originating in Lancashire, especially West Lancashire that is similar to its Cornish counterpart but uses carrot instead of swede.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: Pasties can be found in California in many historical Gold Rush towns, such as Grass Valley and Nevada City.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: The pasty has become a cultural symbol of the Upper Peninsula of Michigan.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: Pasty shops are a significant tourist attraction in the region.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: Additionally, the village of Calumet is home to an annual Pasty Festival.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: Many ethnic groups adopted the pasty for use in the Copper Country copper mines; the Finnish immigrants to the region mistook it for the traditional piirakka and kukko pastries.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: The pasty has become strongly associated with all cultures in this area and in the Iron Range in northern Minnesota.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: Mineral Point, Wisconsin, was the site of the first mineral rush in the United States during the 1830s.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: After lead was discovered in Mineral Point, many of the early miners migrated from Cornwall to this southwestern Wisconsin area.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: Pasties can be found in Wisconsin's largest cities, Madison and Milwaukee, as well as in the far northern region along the border with Michigan's Upper Peninsula.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: A similar local history about the arrival of the pasty in the area with an influx of Welsh and Cornish miners to the area's copper mines, and its preservation as a local delicacy, is found in Butte, Montana, "The Richest Hill on Earth".

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: The anthracite coal region of Northeastern Pennsylvania, including Wilkes-Barre, Scranton, and Hazleton, had an influx of miners to the area in the 19th century and brought the pasty with them.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: In 1981, a Pennsylvania entrepreneur started marketing pasties under the brand name Mr. Pastie.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: The Mexican state of Hidalgo and the twin silver mining cities of Pachuca and Real del Monte (Mineral del Monte) have notable Cornish influences from the Cornish miners who settled there, with pasties being considered typical local cuisine.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: In Mexican Spanish, they are referred to as pastes.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: A pasty museum is located in Real del Monte.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: The annual International Pasty Festival is held in Real del Monte each October.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: They are also popular in South Africa, New Zealand, and Ulster.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: Pasties were modified with different spices and fillings in Jamaica, giving rise to the Jamaican patty.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: Similar dishes are found in many countries such as empanadas in Spanish-speaking countries, Salteña in Bolivia, tourtière in Canada, samsa in Central Asia, and bánh patê sô/pâté chaud in Vietnam.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2:
== Culture ==
=== Literature ===
Pasties have been mentioned in multiple literary works since the 12th century Arthurian romance Erec and Enide, written by Chrétien de Troyes, in which they are eaten by characters from the area now known as Cornwall.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: There is a mention in Havelok the Dane, another romance written at the end of the thirteenth century; in the 14th century Robin Hood tales; and in two plays by William Shakespeare.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2:
=== Superstitions, rhymes and chants ===
In the tin mines of Devon and Cornwall, pasties were associated with "knockers", spirits said to create a knocking sound that was either supposed to indicate the location of rich veins of ore, or to warn of an impending tunnel collapse.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: To encourage the good will of the knockers, miners would leave a small part of the pasty within the mine for them to eat.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: Sailors and fisherman would likewise discard a crust to appease the spirits of dead mariners, though fishermen believed that it was bad luck to take a pasty aboard ship.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: A Cornish proverb, recounted in 1861, emphasised the great variety of ingredients that were used in pasties by saying that the devil would not come into Cornwall for fear of ending up as a filling in one.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: A West Country schoolboy playground-rhyme current in the 1940s concerning the pasty went: Matthew, Mark, Luke and John, ate a pasty five feet long,Bit it once, Bit it twice, Oh my Lord, it's full of mice.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: In 1959 the English singer-songwriter Cyril Tawney wrote a nostalgic song called "The Oggie Man".

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: The song tells of the pasty-seller with his characteristic vendor's call who was always outside Plymouth's Devonport Naval Dockyard gates late at night when the sailors were returning, and his replacement by hot dog sellers after World War II.The word "oggy" in the internationally popular chant "Oggy Oggy Oggy, Oi Oi Oi" is thought to stem from Cornish dialect "hoggan", deriving from "hogen" the Cornish word for pasty.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: When the pasties were ready for eating, the bal maidens at the mines would supposedly shout down the shaft "Oggy Oggy Oggy" and the miners would reply "Oi Oi Oi".

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2:
=== Giant pasties ===
As the 'national dish' of Cornwall, several oversized versions of the pasty have been created in the county.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: For example, a giant pasty is paraded from Polruan to Fowey through the streets during regatta week.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.
Sentence 2: Similarly, a giant pasty is paraded around the ground of the Cornish Pirates rugby team on St Piran's Day before it is passed over the goal posts.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert zurück.

=== Literature ===
Pasties have been mentioned in multiple literary works since the 12th century Arthurian romance Erec and Enide, written by Chrétien de Troyes, in which they are eaten by characters from the area now known as Cornwall.

=== Superstitions, rhymes and chants ===

== History ==
Despite the modern pasty's strong association with Cornwall, its origins are unclear.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: The English word "pasty" derives from Medieval French (O.Fr.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: paste from V.Lat pasta) for a pie, filled with venison, salmon or other meat, vegetables or cheese, baked without a dish.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: Pasties have been mentioned in cookbooks throughout the ages.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: For example, the earliest version of Le Viandier (Old French) has been dated to c. 1300 and contains several pasty recipes.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: In 1393, Le Menagier de Paris contains recipes for pasté with venison, veal, beef, or mutton.Other early references to pasties include a 13th-century charter that was granted by King John of England (in 1208) to the town of Great Yarmouth.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: The town was bound to send to the sheriffs of Norwich every year one hundred herrings, baked in twenty four pasties, which the sheriffs delivered to the lord of the manor of East Carlton who then conveyed them to the king.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: Around the same time, 13th-century chronicler Matthew Paris wrote of the monks of St Albans Abbey "according to their custom, lived upon pasties of flesh-meat".

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: In 1465, 5,500 venison pasties were served at the installation feast of George Neville, archbishop of York and chancellor of England.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: The earliest reference for a pasty in Devon or Cornwall can be found in Plymouth city records of 1509/10, which describe "Itm for the cooke is labor to make the pasties 10d".

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: They were even eaten by royalty, as a letter from a baker to Henry VIII's third wife Jane Seymour confirms: "...hope this pasty reaches you in better condition than the last one ..." In his diaries written in the mid-17th century, Samuel Pepys makes several references to his consumption of pasties, for instance "dined at Sir W. Pen's ... on a damned venison pasty, that stunk like a devil", but after this period the use of the word outside Devon and Cornwall declined.In contrast to its earlier place amongst the wealthy, during the 17th and 18th centuries, the pasty became popular with working people in Cornwall and west Devon, where tin miners and others adopted it because of its unique shape, forming a complete meal that could be carried easily and eaten without cutlery.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: In a mine, the pasty's dense, folded pastry could stay warm for several hours, and if it did get cold, it could easily be warmed on a shovel over a candle.Side-crimped pasties gave rise to the suggestion that the miner might have eaten the pasty holding the thick edge of pastry, which was later discarded, thereby ensuring that dirty fingers (possibly including traces of arsenic) did not touch the food or mouth.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: However, many old photographs show that pasties were wrapped in bags made of paper or muslin and were eaten from end to end; according to the earliest Cornish recipe book, published in 1929, this is "the true Cornish way" to eat a pasty.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: Another theory suggests that pasties were marked at one end with an initial and then eaten from the other end so that if not finished in one sitting, they could easily be reclaimed by their owners.

== Cornish pasty ==
The pasty is regarded as the national dish of Cornwall, and an early reference is from a New Zealand newspaper:In Cornwall, there is a common practice among those cottagers who bake at home of making little pasties for the dinners of those who may be working at a distance in the fields.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: They will last the whole week, and are made of any kind of meat or fruit, rolled up in a paste made of flour and suet or lard.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: A couple of ounces of bacon and half a-pound of raw potatoes, both thinly sliced and slightly seasoned, will be found sufficient for the meal.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: The pasty can be carried in the man's pocket.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: The term "Cornish pasty" has been in use since at least the early 1860s:The Cornish pasty, which so admirably comprises a dinner in itself—meat, potatoes, and other good things well cooked and made up into so portable a form—was a subject of much admiration, and reminded me of the old coaching days, when I secured a pasty at Bodmin in order to take it home to my cook, that it might be dissected and serve as a pattern for Cornish pasties in quite another part of the country.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: Cornish pasties are very popular with the working classes in this neighbourhood, and have lately been successfully introduced into some parts of Devonshire.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: They are made of small pieces of beef, and thin slices of potato, highly peppered, and enclosed in wrappers of paste.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: By the late 19th century, national cookery schools began to teach their pupils to create their own version of a "Cornish pasty" that was smaller and was to be eaten as an "economical savoury nibble for polite middle-class Victorians".On 20 July 2011, after a nine-year campaign by the Cornish Pasty Association (CPA) – the trade organisation of about 50 pasty makers based in Cornwall – the name "Cornish pasty" was awarded Protected Geographical Indication (PGI) status by the European Commission.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: According to the PGI status, a Cornish pasty should be shaped like a 'D' and crimped on one side, not on the top.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: Its ingredients should include beef, swede (called turnip in Cornwall), potato and onion, with a light seasoning of salt and pepper, keeping a chunky texture.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: The pastry should be golden and retain its shape when cooked and cooled.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: The PGI status also means that Cornish pasties must be prepared in Cornwall.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: They do not have to be baked in Cornwall, nor do the ingredients have to come from the county, though the CPA notes that there are strong links between pasty production and local suppliers of the ingredients.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: Packaging for pasties that conform to the requirements includes an authentication stamp, the use of which is policed by the CPA.Producers outside Cornwall objected to the PGI award, with one saying "[EU bureaucrats could] go to hell", and another that it was "protectionism for some big pasty companies to churn out a pastiche of the real iconic product".

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: Major UK supermarkets Asda and Morrisons both stated they would be affected by the change, as did nationwide bakery chain Greggs, though Greggs was one of seven companies allowed to continue to use the name "Cornish pasty" during a three-year transitional period.Members of the CPA made about 87 million pasties in 2008, amounting to sales of £60 million (about 6% of the food economy of Cornwall).

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: In 2011, over 1,800 permanent staff were employed by members of the CPA and some 13,000 other jobs benefited from the trade.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: Surveys by the South West tourism board have shown that one of the top three reasons people visit Cornwall is the food and that the Cornish pasty is the food most associated with Cornwall.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.

== Definition and ingredients ==
The recipe for a Cornish pasty, as defined by its protected status, includes diced or minced beef, onion, potato and swede in rough chunks along with some "light peppery" seasoning.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: The cut of beef used is generally skirt steak.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: Swede is sometimes called turnip in Cornwall, but the recipe requires use of actual swede, not turnip.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: Pasty ingredients are usually seasoned with salt and pepper, depending on individual taste.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: The use of carrot in a traditional Cornish pasty is frowned upon, though it does appear regularly in recipes.The type of pastry used is not defined, as long as it is golden in colour and will not crack during the cooking or cooling, although modern pasties almost always use a shortcrust pastry.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: There is a humorous belief that the pastry on a good pasty should be strong enough to withstand a drop down a mine shaft, and indeed the barley flour that was usually used does make hard dense pastry.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2:
=== Variations ===
Although the officially protected Cornish pasty has a specific ingredients list, old Cornish cookery books show that pasties were generally made from whatever food was available.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: Indeed, the earliest recorded pasty recipes include venison, not beef.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: "Pasty" has always been a generic name for the shape and can contain a variety of fillings, including stilton, vegetarian and even chicken tikka.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: Pork and apple pasties are readily available in shops throughout Cornwall and Devon, with the ingredients including an apple flavoured sauce, mixed together throughout the pasty, as well as sweet pasties with ingredients such as apple and fig or chocolate and banana, which are common in some areas of Cornwall.A part-savoury, part-sweet pasty (similar to the Bedfordshire clanger) was eaten by miners in the 19th century, in the copper mines on Parys Mountain, Anglesey.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: The technician who did the research and discovered the recipe claimed that the recipe was probably taken to Anglesey by Cornish miners travelling to the area looking for work.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: No two-course pasties are commercially produced in Cornwall today, but are usually the product of amateur cooks.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: They are, however, commercially available in the British supermarket chain Morrisons (under the name 'Tin Miner Pasty').

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: Other traditional fillings have included a wide variety of locally available meats including pork, bacon, egg, rabbit, chicken, mackerel and sweet fillings such as dates, apples, jam and sweetened rice - leading to the oft-quoted joke that 'the Devil hisself was afeared to cross over into Cornwall for fear that ee'd end up in a pasty'.A pasty is known as a "tiddy oggy" when steak is replaced with an extra potato, "tiddy" meaning potato and "oggy" meaning pasty and was eaten when times were hard and expensive meat could not be afforded.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: Another traditional meatless recipe is 'herby pie' with parsley, freshly gathered wild green herbs and chives, ramsons or leeks and a spoonful of clotted cream.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.

=== Shape ===
Whilst the PGI rules state that a Cornish pasty must be a "D" shape, with crimping along the curve (i.e., side-crimped), crimping is variable within both Devon and Cornwall, with some advocating a side crimp while others maintain that a top crimp is more authentic.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: Some sources state that the difference between a Devon and a Cornish pasty is that a Devon pasty has a top-crimp and is oval in shape, whereas the Cornish pasty is semicircular and side-crimped along the curve.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: However, pasties with a top crimp have been made in Cornwall for generations, yet those Cornish bakers who favour this method now find that they cannot legally call their pasties "Cornish".

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: Paul Hollywood, writing for BBC Food, stated that a traditional Cornish pasty should have about 20 crimps.

== In other regions ==
Migrating Devonian and Cornish miners and their families (colloquially known as Cousin Jacks and Cousin Jennies) helped to spread pasties into the rest of the world during the 19th century.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: As tin mining in Devon and Cornwall began to decline, miners took their expertise and traditions to new mining regions around the world.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2:

Many parts of Australia, including the Yorke Peninsula, which has been the site of an annual Cornish festival (claimed to be the world's largest) since 1973.

== Culture ==
=== Literature ===
Pasties have been mentioned in multiple literary works since the 12th century Arthurian romance Erec and Enide, written by Chrétien de Troyes, in which they are eaten by characters from the area now known as Cornwall.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: There is a mention in Havelok the Dane, another romance written at the end of the thirteenth century; in the 14th century Robin Hood tales; and in two plays by William Shakespeare.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2:
=== Superstitions, rhymes and chants ===
In the tin mines of Devon and Cornwall, pasties were associated with "knockers", spirits said to create a knocking sound that was either supposed to indicate the location of rich veins of ore, or to warn of an impending tunnel collapse.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: To encourage the good will of the knockers, miners would leave a small part of the pasty within the mine for them to eat.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: Sailors and fisherman would likewise discard a crust to appease the spirits of dead mariners, though fishermen believed that it was bad luck to take a pasty aboard ship.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: A Cornish proverb, recounted in 1861, emphasised the great variety of ingredients that were used in pasties by saying that the devil would not come into Cornwall for fear of ending up as a filling in one.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: A West Country schoolboy playground-rhyme current in the 1940s concerning the pasty went: Matthew, Mark, Luke and John, ate a pasty five feet long,Bit it once, Bit it twice, Oh my Lord, it's full of mice.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: In 1959 the English singer-songwriter Cyril Tawney wrote a nostalgic song called "The Oggie Man".

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: The song tells of the pasty-seller with his characteristic vendor's call who was always outside Plymouth's Devonport Naval Dockyard gates late at night when the sailors were returning, and his replacement by hot dog sellers after World War II.The word "oggy" in the internationally popular chant "Oggy Oggy Oggy, Oi Oi Oi" is thought to stem from Cornish dialect "hoggan", deriving from "hogen" the Cornish word for pasty.

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2: When the pasties were ready for eating, the bal maidens at the mines would supposedly shout down the shaft "Oggy Oggy Oggy" and the miners would reply "Oi Oi Oi".

Sentence 1: Dies hatte praktikable Gründe.
Sentence 2:

The recipe for a Cornish pasty, as defined by its protected status, includes diced or minced beef, onion, potato and swede in rough chunks along with some "light peppery" seasoning.

=== Shape ===
Whilst the PGI rules state that a Cornish pasty must be a "D" shape, with crimping along the curve (i.e., side-crimped), crimping is variable within both Devon and Cornwall, with some advocating a side crimp while others maintain that a top crimp is more authentic.

== Cornish pasty ==
The pasty is regarded as the national dish of Cornwall, and an early reference is from a New Zealand newspaper:In Cornwall, there is a common practice among those cottagers who bake at home of making little pasties for the dinners of those who may be working at a distance in the fields.

== Definition and ingredients ==
The recipe for a Cornish pasty, as defined by its protected status, includes diced or minced beef, onion, potato and swede in rough chunks along with some "light peppery" seasoning.

== Culture ==
=== Literature ===
Pasties have been mentioned in multiple literary works since the 12th century Arthurian romance Erec and Enide, written by Chrétien de Troyes, in which they are eaten by characters from the area now known as Cornwall.

=== Superstitions, rhymes and chants ===
In the tin mines of Devon and Cornwall, pasties were associated with "knockers", spirits said to create a knocking sound that was either supposed to indicate the location of rich veins of ore, or to warn of an impending tunnel collapse.

Sentence 2: Sailors and fisherman would likewise discard a crust to appease the spirits of dead mariners, though fishermen believed that it was bad luck to take a pasty aboard ship.

Pasties have been mentioned in multiple literary works since the 12th century Arthurian romance Erec and Enide, written by Chrétien de Troyes, in which they are eaten by characters from the area now known as Cornwall.

=== Superstitions, rhymes and chants ===
In the tin mines of Devon and Cornwall, pasties were associated with "knockers", spirits said to create a knocking sound that was either supposed to indicate the location of rich veins of ore, or to warn of an impending tunnel collapse.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert blühte der Bergbau in der Region um Cornwall auf und es wurde viel Kupfer und Zinn abgebaut.
Sentence 2: To encourage the good will of the knockers, miners would leave a small part of the pasty within the mine for them to eat.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert blühte der Bergbau in der Region um Cornwall auf und es wurde viel Kupfer und Zinn abgebaut.
Sentence 2: Sailors and fisherman would likewise discard a crust to appease the spirits of dead mariners, though fishermen believed that it was bad luck to take a pasty aboard ship.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert blühte der Bergbau in der Region um Cornwall auf und es wurde viel Kupfer und Zinn abgebaut.
Sentence 2: A Cornish proverb, recounted in 1861, emphasised the great variety of ingredients that were used in pasties by saying that the devil would not come into Cornwall for fear of ending up as a filling in one.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert blühte der Bergbau in der Region um Cornwall auf und es wurde viel Kupfer und Zinn abgebaut.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert blühte der Bergbau in der Region um Cornwall auf und es wurde viel Kupfer und Zinn abgebaut.

Sentence 1: Jahrhundert blühte der Bergbau in der Region um Cornwall auf und es wurde viel Kupfer und Zinn abgebaut.
Sentence 2: The song tells of the pasty-seller with his characteristic vendor's call who was always outside Plymouth's Devonport Naval Dockyard gates late at night when the sailors were returning, and his replacement by hot dog sellers after World War II.The word "oggy" in the internationally popular chant "Oggy Oggy Oggy, Oi Oi Oi" is thought to stem from Cornish dialect "hoggan", deriving from "hogen" the Cornish word for pasty.

== Culture ==
=== Literature ===
Pasties have been mentioned in multiple literary works since the 12th century Arthurian romance Erec and Enide, written by Chrétien de Troyes, in which they are eaten by characters from the area now known as Cornwall.

=== Superstitions, rhymes and chants ===
In the tin mines of Devon and Cornwall, pasties were associated with "knockers", spirits said to create a knocking sound that was either supposed to indicate the location of rich veins of ore, or to warn of an impending tunnel collapse.

Sentence 2: To encourage the good will of the knockers, miners would leave a small part of the pasty within the mine for them to eat.

Sentence 2: Sailors and fisherman would likewise discard a crust to appease the spirits of dead mariners, though fishermen believed that it was bad luck to take a pasty aboard ship.

Sentence 1: Sie diente auch als präventive Maßnahme gegen Arsenvergiftung.
Sentence 2: The song tells of the pasty-seller with his characteristic vendor's call who was always outside Plymouth's Devonport Naval Dockyard gates late at night when the sailors were returning, and his replacement by hot dog sellers after World War II.The word "oggy" in the internationally popular chant "Oggy Oggy Oggy, Oi Oi Oi" is thought to stem from Cornish dialect "hoggan", deriving from "hogen" the Cornish word for pasty.

The recipe for a Cornish pasty, as defined by its protected status, includes diced or minced beef, onion, potato and swede in rough chunks along with some "light peppery" seasoning.

Pasties have been mentioned in multiple literary works since the 12th century Arthurian romance Erec and Enide, written by Chrétien de Troyes, in which they are eaten by characters from the area now known as Cornwall.

=== Superstitions, rhymes and chants ===
In the tin mines of Devon and Cornwall, pasties were associated with "knockers", spirits said to create a knocking sound that was either supposed to indicate the location of rich veins of ore, or to warn of an impending tunnel collapse.

== Definition and ingredients ==
The recipe for a Cornish pasty, as defined by its protected status, includes diced or minced beef, onion, potato and swede in rough chunks along with some "light peppery" seasoning.

Sentence 1: Dabei handelte es sich meist um die Ecke mit den Initialen.
Sentence 2: The cut of beef used is generally skirt steak.

=== Shape ===
Whilst the PGI rules state that a Cornish pasty must be a "D" shape, with crimping along the curve (i.e., side-crimped), crimping is variable within both Devon and Cornwall, with some advocating a side crimp while others maintain that a top crimp is more authentic.

== Culture ==
=== Literature ===
Pasties have been mentioned in multiple literary works since the 12th century Arthurian romance Erec and Enide, written by Chrétien de Troyes, in which they are eaten by characters from the area now known as Cornwall.

=== Superstitions, rhymes and chants ===
In the tin mines of Devon and Cornwall, pasties were associated with "knockers", spirits said to create a knocking sound that was either supposed to indicate the location of rich veins of ore, or to warn of an impending tunnel collapse.

Sentence 1: Dabei handelte es sich meist um die Ecke mit den Initialen.

Sentence 2: A pasty () is a British baked pastry, a traditional variety of which is particularly associated with Cornwall, South West England, but has spread all over the British Isles, and elsewhere through the Cornish diaspora.

Sentence 2: It is made by placing an uncooked filling, typically meat and vegetables, in the middle of a flat shortcrust pastry circle, bringing the edges together in the middle, and crimping over the top to form a seal before baking.

== History ==
Despite the modern pasty's strong association with Cornwall, its origins are unclear.

Sentence 2: The English word "pasty" derives from Medieval French (O.Fr.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.

Sentence 2: Pasties have been mentioned in cookbooks throughout the ages.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: For example, the earliest version of Le Viandier (Old French) has been dated to c. 1300 and contains several pasty recipes.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: In 1393, Le Menagier de Paris contains recipes for pasté with venison, veal, beef, or mutton.Other early references to pasties include a 13th-century charter that was granted by King John of England (in 1208) to the town of Great Yarmouth.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: The town was bound to send to the sheriffs of Norwich every year one hundred herrings, baked in twenty four pasties, which the sheriffs delivered to the lord of the manor of East Carlton who then conveyed them to the king.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: Around the same time, 13th-century chronicler Matthew Paris wrote of the monks of St Albans Abbey "according to their custom, lived upon pasties of flesh-meat".

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: In 1465, 5,500 venison pasties were served at the installation feast of George Neville, archbishop of York and chancellor of England.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: The earliest reference for a pasty in Devon or Cornwall can be found in Plymouth city records of 1509/10, which describe "Itm for the cooke is labor to make the pasties 10d".

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: They were even eaten by royalty, as a letter from a baker to Henry VIII's third wife Jane Seymour confirms: "...hope this pasty reaches you in better condition than the last one ..." In his diaries written in the mid-17th century, Samuel Pepys makes several references to his consumption of pasties, for instance "dined at Sir W. Pen's ... on a damned venison pasty, that stunk like a devil", but after this period the use of the word outside Devon and Cornwall declined.In contrast to its earlier place amongst the wealthy, during the 17th and 18th centuries, the pasty became popular with working people in Cornwall and west Devon, where tin miners and others adopted it because of its unique shape, forming a complete meal that could be carried easily and eaten without cutlery.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: In a mine, the pasty's dense, folded pastry could stay warm for several hours, and if it did get cold, it could easily be warmed on a shovel over a candle.Side-crimped pasties gave rise to the suggestion that the miner might have eaten the pasty holding the thick edge of pastry, which was later discarded, thereby ensuring that dirty fingers (possibly including traces of arsenic) did not touch the food or mouth.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: However, many old photographs show that pasties were wrapped in bags made of paper or muslin and were eaten from end to end; according to the earliest Cornish recipe book, published in 1929, this is "the true Cornish way" to eat a pasty.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: Another theory suggests that pasties were marked at one end with an initial and then eaten from the other end so that if not finished in one sitting, they could easily be reclaimed by their owners.

The pasty is regarded as the national dish of Cornwall, and an early reference is from a New Zealand newspaper:In Cornwall, there is a common practice among those cottagers who bake at home of making little pasties for the dinners of those who may be working at a distance in the fields.

Sentence 2: By the late 19th century, national cookery schools began to teach their pupils to create their own version of a "Cornish pasty" that was smaller and was to be eaten as an "economical savoury nibble for polite middle-class Victorians".On 20 July 2011, after a nine-year campaign by the Cornish Pasty Association (CPA) – the trade organisation of about 50 pasty makers based in Cornwall – the name "Cornish pasty" was awarded Protected Geographical Indication (PGI) status by the European Commission.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: According to the PGI status, a Cornish pasty should be shaped like a 'D' and crimped on one side, not on the top.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: They do not have to be baked in Cornwall, nor do the ingredients have to come from the county, though the CPA notes that there are strong links between pasty production and local suppliers of the ingredients.

== Definition and ingredients ==
The recipe for a Cornish pasty, as defined by its protected status, includes diced or minced beef, onion, potato and swede in rough chunks along with some "light peppery" seasoning.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: The cut of beef used is generally skirt steak.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: Swede is sometimes called turnip in Cornwall, but the recipe requires use of actual swede, not turnip.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: Pasty ingredients are usually seasoned with salt and pepper, depending on individual taste.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: The use of carrot in a traditional Cornish pasty is frowned upon, though it does appear regularly in recipes.The type of pastry used is not defined, as long as it is golden in colour and will not crack during the cooking or cooling, although modern pasties almost always use a shortcrust pastry.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: There is a humorous belief that the pastry on a good pasty should be strong enough to withstand a drop down a mine shaft, and indeed the barley flour that was usually used does make hard dense pastry.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2:
=== Variations ===
Although the officially protected Cornish pasty has a specific ingredients list, old Cornish cookery books show that pasties were generally made from whatever food was available.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: Indeed, the earliest recorded pasty recipes include venison, not beef.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: "Pasty" has always been a generic name for the shape and can contain a variety of fillings, including stilton, vegetarian and even chicken tikka.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: Pork and apple pasties are readily available in shops throughout Cornwall and Devon, with the ingredients including an apple flavoured sauce, mixed together throughout the pasty, as well as sweet pasties with ingredients such as apple and fig or chocolate and banana, which are common in some areas of Cornwall.A part-savoury, part-sweet pasty (similar to the Bedfordshire clanger) was eaten by miners in the 19th century, in the copper mines on Parys Mountain, Anglesey.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: The technician who did the research and discovered the recipe claimed that the recipe was probably taken to Anglesey by Cornish miners travelling to the area looking for work.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: No two-course pasties are commercially produced in Cornwall today, but are usually the product of amateur cooks.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: They are, however, commercially available in the British supermarket chain Morrisons (under the name 'Tin Miner Pasty').

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: Other traditional fillings have included a wide variety of locally available meats including pork, bacon, egg, rabbit, chicken, mackerel and sweet fillings such as dates, apples, jam and sweetened rice - leading to the oft-quoted joke that 'the Devil hisself was afeared to cross over into Cornwall for fear that ee'd end up in a pasty'.A pasty is known as a "tiddy oggy" when steak is replaced with an extra potato, "tiddy" meaning potato and "oggy" meaning pasty and was eaten when times were hard and expensive meat could not be afforded.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: Another traditional meatless recipe is 'herby pie' with parsley, freshly gathered wild green herbs and chives, ramsons or leeks and a spoonful of clotted cream.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2:
=== Shape ===
Whilst the PGI rules state that a Cornish pasty must be a "D" shape, with crimping along the curve (i.e., side-crimped), crimping is variable within both Devon and Cornwall, with some advocating a side crimp while others maintain that a top crimp is more authentic.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: Some sources state that the difference between a Devon and a Cornish pasty is that a Devon pasty has a top-crimp and is oval in shape, whereas the Cornish pasty is semicircular and side-crimped along the curve.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: However, pasties with a top crimp have been made in Cornwall for generations, yet those Cornish bakers who favour this method now find that they cannot legally call their pasties "Cornish".

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: Paul Hollywood, writing for BBC Food, stated that a traditional Cornish pasty should have about 20 crimps.

In 2001, a small American grocery and caterer in Gaylord, Michigan,  Albie's Food, Inc., was sent a cease and desist letter from another US-based food company, The J.M.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: Smucker Company, accusing Albie's of violating their intellectual property rights to the "sealed crustless sandwich".

Sentence 2: Instead of capitulating, Albie's took the case to federal court, noting in their filings that a pocket sandwich with crimped edges and no crust was called a "pasty" and had been a popular dish in northern Michigan since the nineteenth century.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: The Federal Court determined that Albie's Foods did not infringe on J.M.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.

== In other regions ==
Migrating Devonian and Cornish miners and their families (colloquially known as Cousin Jacks and Cousin Jennies) helped to spread pasties into the rest of the world during the 19th century.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: As tin mining in Devon and Cornwall began to decline, miners took their expertise and traditions to new mining regions around the world.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2:
As a result, pasties can be found in many regions, including:
Many parts of Australia, including the Yorke Peninsula, which has been the site of an annual Cornish festival (claimed to be the world's largest) since 1973.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: A clarification of the Protected Geographical Status ruling has confirmed that pasties made in Australia are still allowed to be called "Cornish Pasties".

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: Pasties can be found in California in many historical Gold Rush towns, such as Grass Valley and Nevada City.

Sentence 2: The pasty has become a cultural symbol of the Upper Peninsula of Michigan.

Sentence 2: Pasty shops are a significant tourist attraction in the region.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: Additionally, the village of Calumet is home to an annual Pasty Festival.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: The pasty has become strongly associated with all cultures in this area and in the Iron Range in northern Minnesota.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: Pasties can be found in Wisconsin's largest cities, Madison and Milwaukee, as well as in the far northern region along the border with Michigan's Upper Peninsula.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: The anthracite coal region of Northeastern Pennsylvania, including Wilkes-Barre, Scranton, and Hazleton, had an influx of miners to the area in the 19th century and brought the pasty with them.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: The Mexican state of Hidalgo and the twin silver mining cities of Pachuca and Real del Monte (Mineral del Monte) have notable Cornish influences from the Cornish miners who settled there, with pasties being considered typical local cuisine.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: They are also popular in South Africa, New Zealand, and Ulster.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.

== Culture ==
=== Literature ===
Pasties have been mentioned in multiple literary works since the 12th century Arthurian romance Erec and Enide, written by Chrétien de Troyes, in which they are eaten by characters from the area now known as Cornwall.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: There is a mention in Havelok the Dane, another romance written at the end of the thirteenth century; in the 14th century Robin Hood tales; and in two plays by William Shakespeare.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2:
=== Superstitions, rhymes and chants ===
In the tin mines of Devon and Cornwall, pasties were associated with "knockers", spirits said to create a knocking sound that was either supposed to indicate the location of rich veins of ore, or to warn of an impending tunnel collapse.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: To encourage the good will of the knockers, miners would leave a small part of the pasty within the mine for them to eat.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: Sailors and fisherman would likewise discard a crust to appease the spirits of dead mariners, though fishermen believed that it was bad luck to take a pasty aboard ship.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: A Cornish proverb, recounted in 1861, emphasised the great variety of ingredients that were used in pasties by saying that the devil would not come into Cornwall for fear of ending up as a filling in one.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: A West Country schoolboy playground-rhyme current in the 1940s concerning the pasty went: Matthew, Mark, Luke and John, ate a pasty five feet long,Bit it once, Bit it twice, Oh my Lord, it's full of mice.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: In 1959 the English singer-songwriter Cyril Tawney wrote a nostalgic song called "The Oggie Man".

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: The song tells of the pasty-seller with his characteristic vendor's call who was always outside Plymouth's Devonport Naval Dockyard gates late at night when the sailors were returning, and his replacement by hot dog sellers after World War II.The word "oggy" in the internationally popular chant "Oggy Oggy Oggy, Oi Oi Oi" is thought to stem from Cornish dialect "hoggan", deriving from "hogen" the Cornish word for pasty.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: When the pasties were ready for eating, the bal maidens at the mines would supposedly shout down the shaft "Oggy Oggy Oggy" and the miners would reply "Oi Oi Oi".

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2:
=== Giant pasties ===
As the 'national dish' of Cornwall, several oversized versions of the pasty have been created in the county.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: For example, a giant pasty is paraded from Polruan to Fowey through the streets during regatta week.

Sentence 1: Die Finnen, die Ende des 19.
Sentence 2: Similarly, a giant pasty is paraded around the ground of the Cornish Pirates rugby team on St Piran's Day before it is passed over the goal posts.

=== Superstitions, rhymes and chants ===
In the tin mines of Devon and Cornwall, pasties were associated with "knockers", spirits said to create a knocking sound that was either supposed to indicate the location of rich veins of ore, or to warn of an impending tunnel collapse.

Pen's ... on a damned venison pasty, that stunk like a devil", but after this period the use of the word outside Devon and Cornwall declined.In contrast to its earlier place amongst the wealthy, during the 17th and 18th centuries, the pasty became popular with working people in Cornwall and west Devon, where tin miners and others adopted it because of its unique shape, forming a complete meal that could be carried easily and eaten without cutlery.

Despite the modern pasty's strong association with Cornwall, its origins are unclear.

Sentence 1: Mit den in England bleibenden Finnen blieb die Pasty auch in England populär.

Pen's ... on a damned venison pasty, that stunk like a devil", but after this period the use of the word outside Devon and Cornwall declined.In contrast to its earlier place amongst the wealthy, during the 17th and 18th centuries, the pasty became popular with working people in Cornwall and west Devon, where tin miners and others adopted it because of its unique shape, forming a complete meal that could be carried easily and eaten without cutlery.

Sentence 1: Mit den in England bleibenden Finnen blieb die Pasty auch in England populär.

The recipe for a Cornish pasty, as defined by its protected status, includes diced or minced beef, onion, potato and swede in rough chunks along with some "light peppery" seasoning.

== Culture ==
=== Literature ===
Pasties have been mentioned in multiple literary works since the 12th century Arthurian romance Erec and Enide, written by Chrétien de Troyes, in which they are eaten by characters from the area now known as Cornwall.

=== Superstitions, rhymes and chants ===
In the tin mines of Devon and Cornwall, pasties were associated with "knockers", spirits said to create a knocking sound that was either supposed to indicate the location of rich veins of ore, or to warn of an impending tunnel collapse.

Sentence 1: Mit den in England bleibenden Finnen blieb die Pasty auch in England populär.
Sentence 2: To encourage the good will of the knockers, miners would leave a small part of the pasty within the mine for them to eat.

Sentence 1: Mit den in England bleibenden Finnen blieb die Pasty auch in England populär.
Sentence 2: Sailors and fisherman would likewise discard a crust to appease the spirits of dead mariners, though fishermen believed that it was bad luck to take a pasty aboard ship.

Sentence 1: Mit den in England bleibenden Finnen blieb die Pasty auch in England populär.

Sentence 1: Mit den in England bleibenden Finnen blieb die Pasty auch in England populär.
Sentence 2: A West Country schoolboy playground-rhyme current in the 1940s concerning the pasty went: Matthew, Mark, Luke and John, ate a pasty five feet long,Bit it once, Bit it twice, Oh my Lord, it's full of mice.

Sentence 1: Mit den in England bleibenden Finnen blieb die Pasty auch in England populär.
Sentence 2: In 1959 the English singer-songwriter Cyril Tawney wrote a nostalgic song called "The Oggie Man".

Sentence 1: Mit den in England bleibenden Finnen blieb die Pasty auch in England populär.
Sentence 2: The song tells of the pasty-seller with his characteristic vendor's call who was always outside Plymouth's Devonport Naval Dockyard gates late at night when the sailors were returning, and his replacement by hot dog sellers after World War II.The word "oggy" in the internationally popular chant "Oggy Oggy Oggy, Oi Oi Oi" is thought to stem from Cornish dialect "hoggan", deriving from "hogen" the Cornish word for pasty.

Sentence 1: Mit den in England bleibenden Finnen blieb die Pasty auch in England populär.

=== Literature ===

=== Superstitions, rhymes and chants ===
